appropriations: After December 31, 2025, 4.0 cents per cigarette shall be deposited to the credit of the Hawaii cancer research special fund for research and operating expenses and for capital expenditures. [15] The legislative document specifies that until June 30, 2041, of each amount deposited, 4.0 cents per cigarette shall be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance. policy_impact: The Committee on Ways and Means amended this measure by specifying that the increased tax revenues be deposited into the Hawaii cancer research special fund. [14] It also requires that, until June 30, 2041, all cigarette tax revenues allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance. [14]
capital_expenditure_impact: A portion of the cigarette tax revenue allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund is specifically pledged towards revenue bonds sold to construct the cancer center in 2010. [15] [15] After December 31, 2025, 4.0 cents per cigarette will be deposited to the fund. [15] The legislative document specifies that until June 30, 2041, this amount shall be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance. [15]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The measure requires that, until June 30, 2041, all cigarette tax revenues allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance. [14] The legislative document specifies this allocation is 4.0 cents per cigarette. [15] The Committee finds this addresses the jeopardized revenue stream for debt service for the revenue bonds. updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The Committee on Ways and Means amended the measure to specify that increased tax revenues be deposited into the Hawaii cancer research special fund. [14] This changes the previous version which allocated the increase in tax revenues for debt reduction for the Cancer Research Center of Hawaii. [14] A new provision requires that until June 30, 2041, all cigarette tax revenues allocated to the fund (4.0 cents per cigarette) be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance.
